ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Considering intersections between ethnic studies and current solidarity movements.
I learned more about topics related to my major.
it was interesting seeing how many different talks there were relating to ERM, but unfortunately, i didn't really engage as much with them as I should have
I learned a range of things related to racial systems and activism.
an understanding of ER&M at yale and ethnicity studies as an academic path
Understanding of ERM field and major.
It was incredible to learn from so many scholars, artists, and activists.
I certainly expanded my knowledge on ERM studies, particularly through engaging with professors and researchers outside of Yale whose line of work regards intersectional studies in the ERM world.
Greater understanding of and exposure to the different perspectives and narratives of marginalized identities and communities, different unique art forms and creative works of expression, etc.
I got to attend and interact with courses in ethnicity, race, and migration, in the greater New Haven community and beyond.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A great course to generate broader community in the ERM major.
It's a good way to become more immersed in the community and learn about topics of interest.
strength is that its manageable and you can choose your own talks that interest you. weakness is that on zoom you might not really engage, and there's no student to student engagement. easy .5 credit

I think this is a great low-committment introduction for students looking into an ER&M major. One thing that would have benefitted me would be more info sessions about the major or mentors/faculty making themselves more publicly available for 1-1 conversations about the major for information that we didn't really get from the events.
Good variety of options.
Strengths: It had incredible flexibility and a wide range of options
I wish there was a more organized way to mark down which events I attended at the end, rather than through a discussion post.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i think the class was fine for what it is, an opportunity for students to go to a wide varietry of ERM zoom events.
The range of events we could attend was great and flexible, which was helpful with the circumstances of COVID.
Events could be recorded
This course was really flexible and understanding. I enjoyed it greatly!
I especially appreciated the scheduling and flexibility offered.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!
YES! Free 0.5 credit
Yes!
Yes for all ER&M majors and prospective majors
Yes, if you are in ER&M or interested in majoring in ER&M, it's a great way to receive more credits and expose yourself to really interesting talks hosted by the program.
Absolutely!

if you're interested in seeing diff erm events and want an easy .5 credit, then yeah but i would say this shouldnt be your only intro to erm at yale because it's not super interactive or requiring of a lot of mental rigor. you don't learn more than you want to. in person tho it should probably be better
Yes! It's a great introduction for anyone interested in the major.
Absolutely! If you have any interest at all in ethnic studies, this course is a really great way to not commit to a specific topic within that but explore a great variety of related topics.
Yes, I think it's a fun and interactive way to be introduced to broad concepts within the ER&M department.
Yes! Very engaging and informative events!
Yes, it was a great way to get some exposure to the topics in the ER&M major.
yes - a great stressfree survey of ethnic studies
yes
Yes, if they wanted an easy 5th class and had some interest in ERM.
Yes! You learn so much in the process of exploring through this course. It's worth the time!
Yes! Take this (half-credit) to better connect yourself to the ER&M community and its resources. You'll meet people, faculty and ideas.
Yes

Definitely! Really great choice for a 5th credit and a way to learn more about issues that you care about in a nontraditional classroom setting. Provides an opportunity to hear from the sources themselves on issues like race and gender identity and sexuality and immigration rather than professors who may not have the same firsthand experience.
Yes! Please take this course.

Yes, the variety of events offered allowed me to pursue multiple areas of interest. They were also topics that were timely and connected well to questions I've had brewing throughout my studies in ER&M.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Various online lectures/workshops.
workshops and events related to the field of ER&M
This half-credit course was a series of virtual lectures hosted by the ER&M and RITM departments, out of which we were required to attend at least four before the end of the semester.
we went to different zoom talks
attended 4 meetings for credit
An assortment of virtual events including some lectures, presentations, performances, etc.
This course was measured by participation in several events.
Various live webinars/zoom panels to attend.
We had to attend various virtual panels and events.
n/a
virtual events related to the department
Series of zoom webinars, panels, and other events
Live events
webinar
Virtual lecture series
n/a
virtual workshops/webinars/speakers
Mix of virtual workshops.
Attend ERM events throughout the semester
Webinars, methods workshops, faculty tutorials (all online)
We attended a variety of events with guest speakers.
We attended 4 events as a part of the course
Remote webinars, speaker events, conferences
